{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562927,"name":"Carson Miller","username":"carsongmiller","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/df705f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T14:56:55.512Z","cooked":"

My team has implemented some auto commands using pathplanner, and they work perfectly in the simulation. (We’re using YAGSL). But when we try and run them on the actual robot, they act extremely erratically. Making the rotation motors of the swerve drives spin wildly, making the drive motors move too far, etc.

Does anyone have any advice on what could be causing this? I believe all of the parameters of the robot in the pathplanner settings are correct (weight, size, gear ratios, etc.

For creating the pathplanner path, it’s as simple as could be for us. We create the auto path in the pathplanner gui, then select it using a sendableChooser using this line in our code:

public Command getAutoInitCommand() {
	return autoChooser.getSelected();
}

No setting of PID parameters or anything. The only PID parameters we’re setting anywhere in the code are in the deploy json files used by YAGSL, and those are working well for controlling the swerve drive in teleop.

pidfproperties.json:

{
  "drive": {
    "p": 0.0020645,
    "i": 0,
    "d": 0,
    "f": 0,
    "iz": 0
  },
  "angle": {
    "p": 0.01,
    "i": 0,
    "d": 0,
    "f": 0,
    "iz": 0
  }
}

controllerproperties.json:

{
  "angleJoystickRadiusDeadband": 0.2,
  "heading": {
    "p": 0.4,
    "i": 0,
    "d": 0.01
  }
}

The issue sort of smells like a PID issue to me, like an over-tuned loop. Is there somewhere else that I should be setting PID values?

Any gotchas I might be missing?

Here’s a link to the full repo

And Here’s a link to probably the most relevant file

Can you send a link to your code and the module types and gearing that you are using?

Does your drive work in teleop?

Also the units for PathPlanner settings are not identical to YAGSL so make sure you did the conversions!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T15:33:10.483Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":40,"readers_count":39,"score":18.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496333,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-works-in-sim-causes-erratic-movement-on-real-robot","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-works-in-sim-causes-erratic-movement-on-real-robot/496333/2","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3563291,"name":"Carson Miller","username":"carsongmiller","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/df705f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T19:51:38.250Z","cooked":"

Can you send a link to your code and the module types and gearing that you are using?

  • Added link to the repo above
  • We’re using these exact swerve drives. I set the gearing as 12.8:1 in pathplanner, which is the value that has been working for us in teleop with the swerve drives (set in the physicalproperties.json file, recommended by the YAGSL docs):
{
  "optimalVoltage": 12,
  "robotMass": 110.2311,
  "wheelGripCoefficientOfFriction": 1.19,
  "currentLimit": {
    "drive": 40,
    "angle": 20
  },
  "conversionFactors": {
    "angle": {
      "gearRatio": 12.8,
      "factor": null
    },
    "drive": {
      "diameter": 4,
      "gearRatio": 6.75,
      "factor": null
    }
  },
  "rampRate": {
    "drive": 0.05,
    "angle": 0.05
  }
}

Does your drive work in teleop?

Yes it does

Also the units for PathPlanner settings are not identical to YAGSL so make sure you did the conversions!

Thanks for the reminder–I double checked my config in pathfinder, and I believe it’s all correct:

{
  "robotWidth": 0.8763,
  "robotLength": 1.0033,
  "holonomicMode": true,
  "pathFolders": [
    "SimplePaths",
    "StartRightPaths"
  ],
  "autoFolders": [],
  "defaultMaxVel": 3.0,
  "defaultMaxAccel": 3.0,
  "defaultMaxAngVel": 540.0,
  "defaultMaxAngAccel": 720.0,
  "defaultNominalVoltage": 12.0,
  "robotMass": 57.5,
  "robotMOI": 22.845,
  "robotTrackwidth": 0.546,
  "driveWheelRadius": 0.051,
  "driveGearing": 12.8,
  "maxDriveSpeed": 5.0,
  "driveMotorType": "NEO",
  "driveCurrentLimit": 20.0,
  "wheelCOF": 1.2,
  "flModuleX": 0.295,
  "flModuleY": 0.22,
  "frModuleX": 0.295,
  "frModuleY": -0.22,
  "blModuleX": -0.295,
  "blModuleY": 0.22,
  "brModuleX": -0.295,
  "brModuleY": -0.22,
  "bumperOffsetX": 0.0,
  "bumperOffsetY": 0.0,
  "robotFeatures": []
}

And running the pathplanner auto does work in the sim–just not when we send it to the physical robot

I also realized that I was not correct on us having no other PID parameters set in the code. You can see in the AutonomousSubsystem.java file that P is set to 5, I and D set to 0. And I now realize that this may actually be our problem. Going to try reducing P tonight, as that seems like it could be high.

And another couple side questions if you have a minute:

  • Would you be able to give me an explanation for what these PID loops are for? Are they essentially feedback as far as how far off the expected path the robot is? As opposed to feedback on the motor speeds themselves?
  • Is a gyro or limelight required for what we’re trying to do at all? Or can it be done entirely without them? Because we do have them on the robot, but to my knowledge, are not really trying to use them to do this.
